Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gene Diversity of the VHS Fish Virus: Evolution of Cellular Immune Response and Pathogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Viral Hemorrhagic Septicemia virus (VHSv) is one of the world's most important finfish diseases, impacting both sport fishing and commercial fishing ventures around the globe. VHSv emerged only recently in the Great Lakes, and little is known about how it arrived and why it periodically leads to large scale fish die-offs. The proposed project will examine how VHSv's evolution in the Great Lake region has contributed to its ability to cause disease, and should aid informed predictions about future outbreaks. Thus, the investigations will integrate studies on VHSv evolution with identification of the means by which the virus disrupts immune systems of infected fish, leading to sickness or death. These results should help to identify how specific genetic changes in the virus can lead to either enhanced or reduced impact on infected fish, and thus will provide critical data for understanding the connection between viral genetic changes (i.e., viral evolution) and the host's response. Results will contribute towards more effective prevention, prediction, and control of VHSv, aiding national and international management efforts. Although the work will focus on the spread of VHSv within the Great Lakes region, the studies will have application to other viruses (fish and otherwise). The PIs will design an attractive mobile display for museum exhibits and broader distribution at conferences and public meetings to assist in disseminating the information beyond the scientific community, and will train both graduate and undergraduate students as part of this project.

Each of the aims of the project addresses a specific question about the spread of this disease in the Great Lakes region. Evolutionary diversification patterns and rates of VHSv genes will be evaluated using each protein gene (nv, N, M, L, and P) in strains and substrains, using new and existing samples. Results will determine how these are related to viral selection in new outbreak taxa and areas, and whether and how strains become endemic or epidemic. Cellular and host responses will be assessed to determine how mutations within viral genes that repress fish innate immune responses affect function by comparing VHSv M and P (and other) gene functions among VHSv strains. The project leaders will use reverse genetics to assess the role of M, P and L in modulating innate immune responses and viral pathogenicity. Taken together these results will be valuable in the present understanding of a new emerging and challenging infectious disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Viral Hemorrhagic Septicemia Virus (VHSV), a.k.a. Piscine norvirhabdovirus, is a deadly fish rhabdovirus that infects over 140 species of freshwater, estuarine, and marine fishes around the world. In 2003, an endemic new subgenogroup/substrain of VHSV (IVb) was found in the North American Great Lakes region where it caused massive die-offs of >30 freshwater species. Its presence in the region ha posed a threat to the sport fishing, commercial fishing, and fish farming industries. Although a number of studies had previously assessed the ability of VHSV-IVb to infect various fish species to cause disease, little prior work had focused on the emergence of this virulent subgenogroup (substrain) in the Great Lakes, or the specific molecular determinants of viral pathogenicity that has led to its ability to induce large fish die offs. 

As such, this particular study centered on a novel experimental approach to test the evolutionary dynamics of this emerging pathogen and its hosts. It was our hypothesis that naturally occurring viral variations would alter host-virus interactions and affect disease severity and propagation dynamics. By studying the populations of virus found in the wild, and comparing their genomic sequences with those of viruses used in laboratory studies of gene function and virulence, we proposed that these integrated data could provide critical understanding of evolutionary changes of the virus relative to the hosts? response. In other words, we hoped to correlate the acquisition of changes over time and location with enhanced ability to produce disease.

Our results revealed a number of interesting outcomes, observations, and advances. One published study focused on the molecular roles of the viral genes on host cell function and virus response. They showed clearly that one viral gene in particular, the viral matrix (M) gene, could shut down host responses including antiviral responses. Follow-up studies performed by incorporating specific mutations in VHSV-IVb M identified mutations that could reduce the virus? cytopathic effects on cells without blocking viral replication. These attenuated viruses taught us about the dual functions of viral genes in host suppression and viral replication, and confirmed these functions as targets for learning more about virulence. Follow-up studies on the novirhabdovirus-specific VHSV nonvirion (Nv) gene have progressed in a similar manner, and we are further working to identify both important new information on Nv function, and on its role in viral dissemination. Notably, whole genome sequences revealed that the Nv gene contained the greatest proportion of SNPs (3.8%) and had the highest rate of evolutionary change (9.76x10-5) among the genes, following the non-coding region (NCDS; 4.3% and 1.40x10-4). Gene regions overall were found to be under purifying selection.

The viral evolutionary studies have also provided important new information about the emergence of the IVb substrain, and about the reduced numbers of viral outbreaks observed in the Great Lakes over the past few years.  We discerned considerable geographic spatial structure has characterized the virus across its distribution, with one group most prevalent in the Upper and Central Great Lakes and the other in the Lower Great Lakes region, including the St. Lawrence River system. Virus populations have significantly diverged among the Upper, Central, and Lower Great Lakes, diversifying over time. Spatial divergence has structured the overall patterns of nucleotide substitutions, while amino acid changes increased temporally. VHSV-IVb thus has significantly differentiated across its

Our most recent work, now ready for publication review, has compared virus from an outbreak in 2003 with viruses isolated more recently, which did not cause symptoms or lead to fish die offs.  In a cell culture situation, these more recent isolates were also less able to replicate efficiently, and induced more host cell response.  As VHSV-IVb nears the end of its second decade of evolution in the Great Lakes region, it has continued to change genetically and in virulence. IVb contains fewer SNPS than IVa or I/III, with IVa appearing to evolve the fastest, and rates of IVb and I/III being similar to each other. Our in vitro studies show reduced virulence in more recent isolates of IVb, consistent with other findings and field observations. Overall, VHSV-IVb likely will continue to maintain a subsistence level in local populations, but may infect new areas and populations, given the spread opportunity. Overall, the results of the studies conducted during the course of this grant advanced our understanding of pathogen-host co-evolutionary patterns.
